problem.para: If \EuScript{B}=\Set{ \Vect{a}, \Vect{b}, \Vect{c} } is a basis for a subvector space V of \RNr[n], then any set of three distinct nonzero vectors in V is also a basis of V.

solution.para: This statement is false. For example, the set \Set{ \Vect{a}, 2\cdot \Vect{a}, 3\cdot \Vect{a} } consists of three distinct nonzero vectors in V. But they do not form a basis of V as there are vectors in V which do not belong to the span of \Set{ \Vect{a}, 2\cdot \Vect{a}, 3\cdot \Vect{a} }; examples of such vectors include \Vect{b} and \Vect{c}.
The problem here is: three vectors can be distinct, but fail to be linearly independent. However, linear independence is a critical requirement for the vectors in a basis.
